title: A reminder that CertainlyT DIDN'T make Azir, Tahm, Kindred, Ekko etc.
body:
Sure, Certainly T has made some overloaded, nearly impossible to balance kits before (cough cough Kalista), but he hardly has a monopoly on multiple passive, convoluted scalings, and walls of text for ability descriptions.

Really, the main trend for overloaded champions is that they are recent. Lets face it, as Riot is slowing down champion releases, they are trying to cram as many cool ideas as they can into each one.

And lets be honest. Everything he's made is fun to play and feels REALLY impactful, and I'd even say Thresh is very well balanced and healthy!

CerT isn't the only champion designer that can overload a kit, I agree. But he's the only one that doesn't seem to get the message and consistently overloads his champions.
At least with other champion designs the live balance team can tune their numbers and restrain their power when needed (most of the time), and then there's kits like Thresh and Kalista who can't be significantly weakened by a numbers change. They would need things straight up cut from their kit to try and dial them back.

And again, CerT does not have a monopoly over making unfun champions. ({{champion:83}}) But he is the most consistent for doing so. Other designers realize sooner or later that how fun a champ is to play against is just as important as how fun one is to play as. CerT hasn't seemed to come to grasp with that after years with the company.

CerT also is not the only designer making things that are new to League. Bard makes holes in walls and generates collectible health packs and scales by roaming around. Tahm allows you to transport a teammate across the map. Kindred scales with counterjungling. Gnar has a transformation he has little control over. Reworked GP has his barrel minigame. Reworked Garen has a villain mechanic that he has no control over and that targets only opponents that are getting kills.

CerT could be a good designer if he had another designer lurking over his shoulder, ready to stop him before a kit gets overloaded. He's thoroughly demonstrated that he can't control himself; a bit of restraint would be a huge positive for his designs.

I disagree with {{champion:203}} being in this group because you can't pick her into every game and do amazing. If you pick her into a Vi or J4, for example, that know what they're doing, you're going to be spending more time dead or running away trying to not die than fighting. Kindred also isn't that overloaded - I think the only instance where it feels that way are with her sustain from Wolf and her passive.

Kindred was also just released a week ago. I'd give the champion another one or two weeks before calling her outright OP. Most people prefer to ban new champions than learn how to play against them anyways. That said, I do foresee some possible nerfs in the future, mostly directed at her sustain and Q.

Actually I don't like Kindred for 2 reasons.

-Her dashes are stupid. Honestly this would probably be the best game I've ever played if every champion didn't have mobility. Mobility in this game went from something unique a champion had to something a champion MUST have to be remotely viable. Imagine if my main, Miss Fortune, had a dash. She would skyrocket to pick-or-ban like she was on release since mobility is the part where she sucks so bad at and probably one if not the only things Miss Fortune sucks at, but the fact that mobility is so mandatory is sad. Look at Lucian, he's utter garbage. Low range, trashy poke, none of his abilities do damage until you're really far ahead, and he doesn't do anything any other ADC can't do, HOWEVER he was played in the LCS a ton because of his dash and MS buff. Even though Lucian lost like 95% of his games in competitive play, he was still a common pick SOLELY because he had mobility. (Sorry didn't mean to make this one long)

-She has a 3-hit-2-win thing. It's really old and while it can be balanced It's boring and repetitive now (Ekko, Tahm, then we have Vayne who's constantly played every other game)

I just find that Kindred's poorly designed. Nothing but recycled features into one. There's some interesting and unique things like Wolf's interaction and her ult but still, most of her kit isn't unique by any means.

Garen is not and was not "overpowered"... he was strong -- mostly due to the new Juggernaut items -- and rito took the nerf scalpel to his most vulnerable stat (movement speed). Now he's relatively fine.

Garen actually before the rework was exceptionally strong, but no one would believe me if I didn't say he was just meh. He was able to build 5/6 tank items and be fairly mobile, nearly immune to CC with the right masteries/elixir of iron, nearly immune to damage with all of his base stats and 20% extra bonus AR/MR, and of course more damage.

Right now Garen is fine but I think he's really counterfun with his kit being SO simple and half of it being simply stat modifiers. I think Garen needs to be actually reworked into something identical, he's literally a faceroll champion and while he isn't overpowered now he's not healthy. I think starter champions like Annie should exist in that case of argument but they shouldn't be Tryndamere-tier where low in skill. Not only do these types of champions offer less counterplay but they also offer less ways to outplay you. Garen's biggest way for example to outplay you is to ult you maybe and you flash away by accident and die? Yet at the same time the biggest counterplay to him is the old school "just kite him".

I mained Garen before 5.16 and I have to disagree with nearly everything you're saying. Garen was _never_ "immune to CC" -- it was his greatest weakness, at nearly every stage of the game. Yes, he could become incredibly tanky, and he only needed one damage item to annihilate squishies; but he had and has only one gapcloser, and a very poor one at that. His ability to get kited is legendary; a smart Garen will wait until he's targeted with CC to pop Q, but then nothing is stopping more slows from being piled on top of him, completely shutting down his gapclose. Not only that but he brings almost nothing to a teamfight.

I haven't played as many post-rework Garen games as I would like, so I won't comment on how he performs now; but from what I can tell he functions basically the same.

But seriously, you are so wrong about Garen. Yes, he's a faceroll champion, but that's what he is meant to be. Garen is about brute forcing your way into the enemy's composition, going hard as a motherfucker 24/7. That is his essence, his lifeblood. I don't even give a damn whether or not it's healthy, because the fact is that it's _fun_; it's so refreshing to have a champion that doesn't rely on Korean-tier mechanics or even all that much strategic decision-making, but instead on having the courage to dive balls deep and win through attrition. There is nothing wrong with simple champions; in fact, simplicity is the key to brilliance. There is more to this game than making plays, you know.

Threshs problem isnt his balance, its that he is almost THE perfect support. So what reason do you have to pick anything else? 
Now Riot could bring out better supports, but with thresh being among the best at about 90% of what he does, anything that was completely better than him would be disgusting. 
What thresh did was hit the quality of supports so high that he was the prime that either should never be reached, or only at the end.

Imagine a footbal player in his 20s who won FIFA. What do you do after that? Everything else pales in comparison. Thresh is the same effect.

I don't think thresh is best at what he does, but he is THE generalist pick. Gotta pick a support early? Thresh wont let you down!

Let me give you an analogy to why Thresh is a problem.

Let's say each champ does 4 things max, each mark out of 100 for effectiveness. And ofc the balanced level would be 50% after averaging all 4 categories.

Specialists are people who perhaps perform 1 thing at 100% and rest for around 30%. 

Generalists would be having everything at 50%.

Then Thresh is a champ who has everything at 60 to 70%. Sure he may not be the strongest in 1 thing, but overall after average he is still OP as hell.

This is not the exact representation but I recon it's close enough. Many overloaded champs like say Lee are problematic in the same way.
